definition: one country, two systems (PRC proposal regarding Hong Kong, Macau and Taiwan)
one/1/single/a (article)/as soon as/entire/whole/all/throughout/"one" radical in Chinese characters (Kangxi radical 1)/also pr. [yao1] for greater clarity when spelling out numbers digit by digit
surname Guo
country/nation/state/national/CL:個|个[ge4]
two/both/some/a few/tael, unit of weight equal to 50 grams (modern) or 1⁄16 of a catty 斤[jin1] (old)
to manufacture/to make
system/to control/to regulate/variant of 製|制[zhi4]

sentences.english: Hong Kong’s return marks the great success of the concept of “one country, two systems.”
sentences.chinese: 香港回归祖国，标志着“一国两制”构想的巨大成功。

sentences.english: The host's remark: The policy of "One country, two systems" enforced by the Hong Kong SAR is unprecedented in history.
sentences.chinese: 香港特别行政区实施的“一国两制”政策史无先例。

sentences.english: The concept of "one country, two systems" is a unique contribution made by the Chinese nation to mankind's political development.
sentences.chinese: “一国两制”是中华民族对人类政治文明的独特贡献。

sentences.english: Unprecedentedly, China agreed that the transfer would happen on the basis of “one country, two systems”.
sentences.chinese: 中国同意在一国两制的基础上进行改变。

sentences.english: The successful practice of "one country, two systems" has completely convinced the public.
sentences.chinese: “一国两制”的成功实践，让人心悦诚服。

definition: Hong Kong Basic Law (in effect since the resumption of Chinese sovereignty in 1997)
system of constitutional government/(used as an attributive) constitutional
basic law (constitutional document)
judicial independence
1992 Consensus, statement issued after 1992 talks between PRC and Taiwan representatives, asserting that there is only one China
political reform
Taiwan independence/(of Taiwan) to declare independence
One-China principle, the official doctrine that Taiwan is a province of China
democracy/democratic

special administrative region (SAR), of which there are two in the PRC: Hong Kong 香港 and Macau 澳門|澳门/refers to many different areas during late Qing, foreign occupation, warlord period and Nationalist government/refers to special zones in North Korea and Indonesia
Hong Kong independence
anti-secession law of 2005 (whereby PRC claims the right to invade Taiwan)
self-determination
to rule according to the law
territorial integrity
Leung Chun-ying (1954-), 3rd Chief Executive of Hong Kong
